ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Column No : 484

FOREIGN WORKERS IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS

     1.  Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng asked the Minister for National Development (a) what will be the impact if all Singaporeans do not want to have the presence of foreign workers in their residential areas; and (b) what specific strategies will the Government adopt to allay the concerns of residents whose neighbourhood is affected by the over-congestion of foreign workers.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan):  Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to answer part (a) of Ms Denise Phua's Question first. In land scarce Singapore, it is not possible to totally segregate foreign workers from the local community.  If Singaporeans do not want to see foreign workers near their residential areas or using common facilities, this will set a physical limit on the number of foreign workers we can accommodate, which will, in turn, limit our economic growth, raise our business costs as well as the cost of living generally.

 

     If Singaporeans do not want foreign workers in their residential areas, then there may be more illegal housing, that is, many foreign workers will continue to overcrowd in improper housing premises within or near residential areas.  This may create even greater health and safety risks, not just to the workers, but also to the surrounding community.

 

     Due to the exceptional increase in foreign worker numbers in the past years, there is a current shortage in foreign worker housing.  Hence, MND is exploring temporary measures, such as housing them in vacant state properties or temporary dormitories built on state land, that may be nearer to residential areas.  The temporary dormitories are needed as many of these workers are already here and living in overcrowded conditions.  Nevertheless, going forward, we will monitor the economic situation closely and adjust our longer-term dormitory supply according to the changing demand for housing.

 

     The Acting Minister for Manpower will be addressing part (b) of the Member's Question in his reply to the next question.

 

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines):  Sir, much has been said about the problems that foreign workers pose, in terms of accommodation.  Can I ask the Minister whether he agrees that as a decent society, it is our duty to provide the foreign workers in our midst decent and humane housing, so that they can come here and earn an honest wage and not feel like modern-day slave in Singapore?  Can I also ask the Minister whether he agrees that if MND were to build trees in housing the foreign workers in the estates, the trees should be built to give them a better environment and not to block them from the sight of Singaporeans?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:   I think there is a responsibility for us to make sure that the foreign workers, and indeed all workers, just like all Singaporeans, are housed in decent conditions.  That is the reason why we have utilised several ways in order to provide proper housing for the workers.  First of all, they can rent private residential premises.  But we have a limit on these premises.  We do not want overcrowding in these premises.  And that is the reason why we have to look at other alternatives.  So construction workers are housed on-site as far as possible.  There is, again, a limit to the number of workers that we can house on-site.  And this is why we need to have another option, which is allowing foreign workers to live in some of our industrial estates.  We have allowed factory owners to convert some of their industrial premises into dormitories.  Last but not least, we provide purpose-built permanent dormitories for these workers and, in these dormitories, amenities are put in place which will provide the workers with a very decent standard of living.  There are minimum living space conditions, living space requirements as well as provisions of all the basic amenities and indeed more than that.  Some of the modern foreign worker dormitories, in fact, have fully equipped gymnasiums, cinemas, games area, and so on.  So they are actually very adequately provided for.


     It is precisely because we want to provide proper housing for these workers that we are now seeking to convert some of the vacant state properties into temporary premises.  There is currently overcrowding in some of the private residential estates, including HDB, and that is a fact that we have to deal with.  So we are now trying to quickly bring up to speed some of these temporary accommodation.  The Serangoon Garden Technical School was one such facility.  It was ready for occupation in a short time.  The facilities are there.  There is sufficient space for us to put in all the amenities that I talked about earlier.  So, yes, I think it is important for us to provide proper housing for all our workers, not just from the point of view of humanity, as Ms Ng put it, but also because there are basic standards of fire safety and basic standards of health and sanitation that we need to take into account.


       But, at the same time, I think we want to make sure that as we roll out these dormitories, the disamenities to the surrounding areas are  minimised.  That is a balance we have to strike.  Hence all the additional features and facilities that we put in, like the road which, by the way, is not just going to serve the dormitory. In future when the site is used for other purposes, once the dormitory moves out, that road will still be relevant and useful.  So it is something that will be useful even beyond the lifespan of the dormitory.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to what extent are the local residents, where the dormitories are to be erected, involved in the whole planning process, in terms of amenities to be built or even roads to be constructed to specially cater to this group of foreigners.  The reason I ask this question is that, if the local residents were involved to a certain extent, I think it will help to build that ownership of these foreigners coming in to live amongst them.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:   Let me explain the process by which we select these premises and also the process of consultation which is relevant to Mdm Ho's question.  First of all, when we scan through the list of sites that are available in Singapore, we take into account, not just the availability, but what are the competing uses because there are many other competing uses for these temporary state properties.  Having decided that that particular site is suitable for a dormitory, we then go through the process of evaluating the technical feasibility of it.  What this means is that we consult the different agencies, like LTA for traffic amenities, NEA to check whether their health or safety buffers are already in place, which means that we would not be able to make use of it, or other facilities or amenities like sewerage, power, and so on.  Having gone through the technical consultation and if we find the sites suitable and feasible, we then consult the advisors and also the grassroots leaders.  This is the stage where the grassroots leaders are brought into play and this is where any concerns are brought up, and we look at ways of minimising those concerns.


     I agree that it is important for us to take that step,  to take into account as far as possible the concerns and also put in the mitigating measures.  I do have to highlight however that not all the proposals are doable, either because they are too expensive or physically it is just not possible.  For example, in the Serangoon Garden case, there was a suggestion to divert the road to another area.  We studied it, LTA looked at it, and came to a conclusion that from the traffic safety and traffic hazard point of view, it was not a good idea to redirect that road.  There was another suggestion to try to block the disamenities, arising from building the road, ie, to try to block some of the noise, the dust or fumes from the road to the residents.  This, we have accepted.  So NParks will be planting some trees.  So where the concerns are valid and where the mitigating measures are doable, we will certainly take them into account.


     But I must come back to the fundamental point which is really that over the last couple of years, we have seen this very sharp rise in the numbers.  These numbers are here and we have to accommodate them, and to accommodate them we need to look at not just permanent sites but also temporary sites, and where the temporary sites are chosen and where they cause some inconvenience and disamenities, then let us look at how we can minimise those inconveniences.  But it will not go away totally.  I think this is something that we all have to accept.

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah):   I understand that we are a land scarce city and have little choice in locating our foreign worker dormitories.  But have we considered putting some of them in the outer islands, for example, Jurong Island, where it could have better spacing and we do not have this kind of problem with regard to space in the residential areas?  In terms of logistics, moving up and down, I think we have done that before in Pulau Tekong with our NSmen, by ferrying them up and down through ferries.  The second question is this.  We seem to be rushing to build a lot more temporary dormitories, and I understand that there could be demand today.  But looking at the current economic situation where there is slow down in the manufacturing, construction and services sectors, do we still need so many dormitories in the residential areas?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:   We do try to house the foreign workers as close as possible to their worksites.  That is the reason why I said earlier that for construction workers, the first choice is really to provide on-site housing for them.  But, again, you must realise that if the construction site is actually quite close to a residential area, there is a limiting constraint there.  In the case of Jurong Island, you will be pleased to know that we actually do have dormitories on Jurong Island.  In fact, there are two dormitories on Jurong Island and they cater to about 10,000 bed spaces.  These are mainly for the process workers, the workers involved in building the petrochemical industries on Jurong Island itself.  That is obviously the most sensible thing to do and where it is feasible, we will do it.


     Just to give Members another example.  A huge number of foreign workers are working on the Marina Bay and also on the Sentosa IRs, and so we try to find dormitory space at or near the sites.  In fact, some of them are staying on-site, and some of them are staying just slightly away from it.  So this is our first choice.  But having exhausted this first choice, we now need to go on to the other choices.  When we talk about looking for temporary dormitory spaces, we are actually looking at the third or even the fourth alternative.


     On his second question: do we need such a number of bed spaces if the economy slows down?  The demand that has been generated now is due to the exceptional surge in the numbers over the last two years.  That is the reason why we need these temporary dormitory spaces.  Going forward, of course, we would have to monitor the situation very closely and, if necessary, we would be adjusting the number of bed spaces to deal with it.  But I can say that as at this moment, and, in fact, for next year, because the demand, especially for construction workers, is still going to be there because projects are still ongoing, I do not foresee that there will be a drastic drop in the demand for foreign workers.

     Mr Speaker:  Mdm Cynthia Phua, last question.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied):   Mr Speaker, Sir, I have two supplementary questions.  In Singapore, we have the Masterplan which is reviewed every 10 years, and then the DGP plan every five years.  In this case, there is an ad hoc request for land use.  I want to ask what is the process for approval of ad hoc use because compatibility of use is important in land use planning.  Can the Minister explain the process of this land use per se in the midst of a residential estate?  The second question is, how does this acute shortage come about because any employment of foreign workers needs the approval of MOM?  Does it mean that there is no communication at all between MOM and MND?

 

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:   As Mdm Cynthia Phua said,  we do have a long-term land use plan, ie, the Masterplan, which is reviewed every five years.  What the Masterplan does is to stipulate the land use plan for various sites in Singapore.  But, at the same time, even with the Masterplan, because land is so scarce in Singapore, we do consider short-term uses for state land.  Why do we do this?  Because (a) it provides flexibility in land use; and (b) more importantly, it allows us to make better use of the land.  If you leave the land empty and do not use it at all because there is no urgency for the longer-term use of the land, then obviously that land is going to waste.  So there is a wastage or under-utilisation of land on the one hand, and there is a demand on the other hand.  If we match the two together, this is where we try to get the compatibility that Mdm Cynthia Phua talked about.  I will give Members several examples.  There was a shortage in office space a few years ago.  We realised that we were not able to generate the additional office space in such a short period of time due to a huge surge in  demand for office space in the last two years.  So the solution was to tender out sites for temporary office space,  for use as transitional office space and, hence,  make use of vacant state properties. 

 

 


     These are the short-term uses that I am talking about. So while the Masterplan reflects the longer term planning intention of the site, it does not preclude us from making better use of the land, if it is still vacant, for short term use. This is precisely the situation for the Serangoon Garden site. The Serangoon Garden site's long-term land use planning intention is for it to be a residential site, but there is no need to tender out the site for residential use. There is no urgency for it. So what do we do? Do we leave it vacant or do we look for alternative use? 


     There are several alternative uses. We find which is the one that is the most compatible. That is the reason why we decided to – after looking at all the feasibility studies – allocate it for foreign worker dormitory. That is the reason why we go for temporary uses even though we have a more permanent planning intention in mind.


     The Member also asked whether there was miscommunication between MDA and MOM. We do have a long-term planning framework in place which takes into account demand for foreign worker bed spaces and housing, which in turn, is related to economic growth in the various sectors. So this planning framework allows us to plan in advance – which is all very fine if the planning parameters or assumptions are as indicated. But in this particular case, the economic growth in the last few years was more robust than anticipated. Just to give Members some figures, construction demand in 2006, when we just came out of the recession, was $17 billion. This year, we expect construction demand to be something like $30 billion, in the space of two years. The number of foreign workers in 2006 went up by 55,000. In 2007, it went up by 102,000, in the space of just one year. And this is not just construction, this is across all sectors – manufacturing, processes, services.


     We could have said, "Let us not allow the foreign workers to come in, because this is not what we have planned for. We do not have the space for  them to come in. Let us say no to foreign workers." What would that mean? If we did not have the number of foreign workers that came in, that would have impacted our growth. That would have impacted the cost of doing business. That would, in fact, have impacted the cost of living because when they come in, there is a reduction in the cost of doing business and, hence, the cost of living. It also meant higher construction cost and delays. So when MPs and residents ask us for upgrading projects, "When is it coming? When is the lift upgrading coming? Where are the flats? Why are we not building enough flats?", all this ultimately boils down to whether we have the resources to build and to upgrade. And what are the resources? It is the foreign workers.


     So, to say no would have created other problems for our economy and our general cost of living. So, we decided to say yes. We decided to go for growth, and then to find ways and means to solve the down-stream problem of looking for housing for them. It is not an easy issue to tackle. It is a challenge. It requires residents to bear with some inconvenience and to make some adjustments. It requires advisers to work the ground to try to convince their residents that overall, on balance, there is a benefit to the economy, to the country and to them ultimately.


     Sir, I submit that this is still the best policy for us, that we go for growth, grab the opportunities when we get them, and where there is a resource constrain, we find ways and means to try to work through the problems.

 

Column No : 493

FOREIGN WORKERS IN HDB ESTATES

(Integration programmes)

     2.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Acting Minister for Manpower given that there is an increase in the number of foreigners being housed in HDB housing estates: (a) how can we ensure that foreigners comply with good housekeeping and security standards; (b) how are orientation and induction programmes carried out for these foreigners living in the midst of our heartland estates; and (c) what special programmes are being organised to socialise and integrate these foreigners.

     The Acting Minister for Manpower (Mr Gan Kim Yong):   Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Minister for National Development has explained, foreign workers make a significant contribution to our economic growth and, indeed, we do face a shortage of these workers today. Therefore, I think it is more important for us to have sufficient housing capacity to accommodate foreign workers here, while reducing the impact on residents. We do this in several ways.

 

     First, we work through the landlords or dormitory operators. HDB flat owners who wish to sublet their whole flat must apply to HDB for approval. They must ensure that their tenants maintain and upkeep the flat and avoid causing nuisance and disamenities to others. If their tenants do not comply with these conditions, HDB will revoke the approval. HDB conducts half-yearly flat inspections for approved subletting cases to ensure that the subletting is in order. For dormitory operators, we require them to provide basic amenities and recreational facilities within the dormitories, to minimise the need for foreign workers to leave the dormitories. We have also broadened the range of amenities, in response to ground feedback.

 

     Second, we reach out to foreign workers to educate them on Singapore's laws and social norms. For example, MOM produces a guidebook in nine languages for distribution to all foreign workers when they arrive in Singapore. The Police has also produced posters and a video in various languages to enhance crime prevention awareness among foreign workers here. These are shown at dormitory roadshows and other events involving foreign workers. NEA has also stepped up educational outreach to foreign workers on public health issues, including putting up banners in the native languages of the foreign workers at areas where they gather and broadcasting anti-littering messages in the buses that ferry foreign workers. Where necessary, the Police and NEA have stepped up enforcement efforts to deter crime and public health offences.

 

     Third, we engage and involve the community. Under the Community Safety and Security Programme, the Police appoint foreign workers as Crime Prevention Ambassadors in residential areas near dormitories. These ambassadors perform foot patrols together with grassroots volunteers to deter crime and socially irresponsible acts near their dormitories. The People's Association's grassroots organisations, such as Community Clubs and Residents' Committees, also organise community activities to promote understanding among residents. During community events, exhibition booths are set up with messages on harmonious living.

 

     MOM and other Government agencies will continue to work with local communities to address their concerns about the presence of foreign workers in the community. By working together in partnership, we can make our communities a better place for Singaporeans, as well as foreigners who are here.

     Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng (Jalan Besar):   Sir, I come from a veteran estate where foreign workers are a common sight, and I have worked on many of the strategies that the Minister has spoken about. I thank the Minister for the slew of strategies that are explained. I do believe, however, the configuration of the strategies is very important. For example, education, posters and banners may not work as effectively for the foreign workers who are normally transient in nature.

 

     Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to consider two more aggressive strategies, one of which is the use or deployment of a budget to hire, for example, uniformed patrol – not necessary armed – to regularly patrol the residential areas to deter, counsel and educate the foreign workers at the void decks regarding their undesirable behaviours.

 

     The second strategy is to place greater accountability on the employers themselves so that they will be responsible for errant workers, and not just have the grassroots, the community or the Police handle all the errant behaviour. Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to consider these more aggressive short-term strategies, besides the long-term ones.

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:   Sir, I would like to thank Ms Denise Phua for the suggestions. We will look into the suggestions that she has pointed out. Some of the strategies and practices will differ from area to area, depending on the conditions on the ground. It is also important for us to engage the community to better understand the concerns of the residents, and we will develop programmes and strategies to cater to the needs of the respective areas where such problems occur.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo:   Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether his Ministry is aware of the kind of issues brought about by foreign workers living in the midst of our local residents. Is there an inter-agency body that would seriously consider all the inputs and views brought up and that would also represent the views of the local residents as well as the local grassroots organisations?

 

     When social behaviour is an issue, and because of the congestion that we face in living in the locality, would the Minister, together with the Ministry of National Development, consider, for example, floating dormitories on water? And since we are bursting at the seams, is there a possibility for us to rent space, maybe across the border, from our good neighbour, Johor, to build dormitories?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, Sir, from the way the questions were answered between MOM and MND, it goes to show that it is a multi-agency concern with regard to the provision of housing for foreign workers. Therefore, indeed, a multi-agency committee co-chaired by MOM and MND has been set up since 2006 to oversee the overall provision of housing, social and recreational facilities for foreign workers here.

 

     With regard to the proposal for floating dormitories, as well as other alternatives across the border, I think these are issues which we will leave to the Ministry of National Development to consider.

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio):   Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether landed properties, such as terrace and semi-detached houses, are allowed to be used to house foreign workers. They do not come under HDB. Which department regulates them? And is there any limit on the number of workers to be housed in such houses?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, Sir, again, this is really for MND to answer. But I will answer it and, hopefully, MND agrees with me. [Laughter].

 

     I think residential properties are allowed to be used to accommodate, on a restricted basis, foreign workers. I think for properties that accommodate more than eight foreign workers, they will have to be dormitories. But for those casual letting of space for foreign workers on a smaller scale, they are allowed under URA.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong:   Sir, there seems to be a stark 'us and them' mentality at play here. Can I ask the Acting Minister whether he agrees that, in fact, Singaporeans are not very different from foreign workers here, except that Singapore has advanced within the last 40-50 years from a third-world country to a first-world country, whereas the foreign workers come from countries which still remain as third-world countries? Yet, 40-50 years ago, Singaporeans had the same low level of skills and education, and our social behaviour was no better than the foreign workers that we have with us today.

 

     Can I ask the Minister whether we should do more to educate Singaporeans that foreign workers are indeed a very integral part of our society in terms of helping us grow? And while we might want to make sure that they do not cause our social fabric to fray, we have to regard them as really our guests.

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:   Mr Speaker, Sir, Ms Irene Ng raised a very important point and I would like to take this opportunity to share my views on this issue.

 

     I think it is important for us to understand that Singaporeans do have concerns when the community is getting more crowded than before, not just because there are foreign workers, but because the sheer number has increased. At the same time, we also understand that some of these foreign workers come from different backgrounds and cultures, have different traditions and practices and, some have different religions as well.


The lifestyle of these foreign workers and our locals are different, and we have to also understand the stress and the tension between the locals and the foreign workers who are here.  The tension and concern, to some extent, are real and we can find solutions to address these concerns.  But it is also important, like Ms Irene Ng pointed out, that we should also find ways to increase our ability to be more inclusive.  I think there is capacity to do so.  Singaporeans, by and large, are very inclusive.  We can encourage and appeal to their inclusiveness within them and, hopefully, over time, we will be able to work together among all the stakeholders – the employers, the foreign workers as well as Singaporeans together with grassroots organisations, the community, and the Government agencies.  We can work together to improve the overall environment to make Singapore more inclusive, at the same time understand the stress and the tension that exist, and find solutions to address these issues where we can.

Column No : 499

     Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me first to explain the basis of the formula used to determine the electricity tariffs for households, and the rationale for the recent tariff increase.

 

     SP Services Ltd, which is a subsidiary of Singapore Power, buys electricity from the generation companies and on-sells it to households.  The components of the electricity tariff are: (a) cost of fuel for power generation which accounts for 62% of the overall costs; (b) non-fuel costs of generation (21%); (c) cost of transmission and distribution (16%); and (d) miscellaneous fees like meter reading and billing (1%).

 

     About 80% of our electricity is generated using natural gas.  In the US, there is a separate and distinct market for natural gas which determines its price.  In Asia, however, there is no such distinct market and the price of natural gas is indexed to the price of fuel oil, which is the alternative fuel for power generation.  So many have wondered why if we use gas to generate electricity, why is there a link to oil, and this is the reason, because you index it to the next best alternative.  Countries like Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Singapore buy natural gas through long-term contracts at a price which is tied to the current price of fuel oil.  Therefore, when the fuel oil price increases, so too will the natural gas price with a consequential increase in our electricity tariffs.

 

     Therefore, SP Services adjusts the electricity tariff every quarter to reflect changes in the cost of fuel oil.  Since 2004, SP Services has pegged the tariff to a three-month forward fuel oil price.  This forward fuel oil price is not a projection.  It is the actual price in the commodities market for future delivery of fuel oil in three months' time.  This is in contrast to spot price of fuel oil which is the price paid for immediate delivery to customers.


     Why use the three-month forward fuel oil price and not the spot price to set the electricity tariff?  The aim is to provide as much certainty as possible to consumers.  A formula based on spot price, which is usually more variable, would mean households experiencing frequent and more volatile changes in their electricity tariffs.

 

     Sir, I have asked the Clerk of Parliament to distribute a chart* which compares the spot fuel oil price and the three-month forward fuel oil price since January 2004.  It is clear from the Chart that the spot fuel oil price has greater variability compared to the three-month forward fuel oil price used by SP Services.  Members should also note that the three-month forward fuel oil price used in the formula has been lower than the spot fuel oil price in all but five of the 16 quarters since 2004.  In other words, the forward fuel oil price number that has been used in the formula to set tariffs had been lower than the spot price and, therefore, the impact on the electricity tariffs is to have it low.  Although the tariff formula using this three-month forward fuel oil price cannot insulate the price of electricity from the rising and volatile price of oil, it does help to moderate the impact.

 

     Sir, Mdm Ho Geok Choo has asked and Ms Ellen Lee is about to ask why tariff is increasing when spot prices are falling.  With the current approach, there is a three-month time lag between changes in the fuel oil price and the actual tariff revision and this time lag works both ways, ie, electricity tariffs move up more slowly when fuel oil prices are rising, and move down more slowly when fuel oil prices are falling.  For instance, in July 2008, the spot fuel oil price was Singapore dollars – we converted everything to Singapore dollars – $153 a barrel, which was higher than the corresponding three-month forward fuel oil price of S$112 a barrel.  So in July this year, if we had used the spot price to compute the electricity tariffs, it would have been 21% higher than that computed using the three-month forward price.

 

     The converse is true in the current quarter, with the average spot fuel oil price in October  (about S$109 a barrel) being lower than the corresponding three-month forward fuel oil price (S$155 barrel).  If the current lower fuel oil prices are sustained, the benefits will flow through with the same time lag to electricity tariffs in the next quarter.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, on balance, under the current formula, the volatility of electricity tariffs has been relatively low and households have generally paid less for their electricity than if we had used spot prices, as indicated by the green shaded areas of the Chart.  The Energy Market Authority (EMA) is studying whether the formula can be further improved. 

 

     To Ms Sylvia Lim's question, I would caution that we should refrain from making arbitrary changes just because the outcomes are inconvenient in a particular quarter or two.  What we ought to really think about is, if we make such changes and if they are not well thought out and they are seen by the market to be arbitrary, that would increase regulatory risks, adversely affect investors' sentiment and confidence and, ultimately, it will do more harm than good to our consumers and businesses.

 

     The Government has sought to mitigate the impact of the rise in electricity prices by providing focused and targeted assistance through U-save rebates for those who need help the most.  We are also conducting programmes to raise awareness of electricity conservation and facilitate efforts by households and businesses to reduce their utility bills.  We have opted not to subsidise electricity because this encourages over-consumption and is unsustainable in the long run, as it is quite evident from the experience of many countries.

 

     Ms Lee Bee Wah has asked what has been done to ensure that the pricing by energy companies is reasonable.  Since the liberalisation of the electricity industry, the EMA has ensured that electricity tariffs are set efficiently through competition in the electricity generation market, and by regulating Singapore Power on its tariffs for the transmission and distribution of electricity, because Sing Power is a regulated monopoly and also by regulating SP Services, which retails electricity to households.  EMA has both in-house expertise and external consultants to advise on its regulation of the electricity industry.

 

     The liberalisation of the electricity industry has brought about greater competition and efficiency gains among the power generation companies and these have been passed on as real benefits to our consumers.  This is clear from the fact that although fuel oil prices have risen substantially by more than 300% since the onset of competition in 2001, electricity tariffs have risen by about 50%.

 

     With the sale of the power generation companies by Temasek Holdings, a point that Mr Gautam Banerjee has raised, we can expect market competition to continue to exert downward pressure on electricity prices without compromising the reliability and security of our energy supply.  This is because our electricity market regime allows and encourages new generation plants to be built, which incentivises generation companies to innovate and produce or provide electricity at competitive rates.  Senoko Power, for example, which was recently sold to a foreign consortium, has since decided to invest in repowering its oil-fired plants with the more efficient gas generators.  The divestment of the power companies will benefit Singaporeans over the long term as it will enhance competition, help raise our industry standards to international levels by attracting global energy players, and promote innovation in our energy industry.
 
     Ms Lee Bee Wah has also asked how Singapore Power (SP) is regulated to ensure that its revenues are translated into benefits for households and businesses in Singapore.  Singapore Power’s electricity transmission and distribution and its retail business are regulated by the EMA to ensure that the electricity supply is reliable and affordable. In particular, the electricity grid is regulated such that Sing Power is incentivised to enhance system efficiency, and the savings from such efficiency gains are passed on to consumers.  In fact, Singapore Power has announced that from 1st October 2008, the charges for transporting electricity have been reduced by between 8% and 11%. 
 
     On Mdm Ho Geok Choo’s suggestion for more clarity on the electricity pricing model, EMA will put out more information on its website to help Singaporeans understand how electricity is priced.  EMA is also taking steps to further liberalise the electricity market for households.  It has developed a prototype Electricity Vending System (EVS) which allows households to purchase electricity from competing providers with different price plans.  Feedback from the upcoming EVS trial runs will allow EMA to evaluate the system, establish its viability, and it will eventually open the market for more retailers to compete to sell electricity directly to households.

     The total return approach which marks the investments to current market value takes into consideration the appreciation and depreciation of the reserves invested.  This approach, especially in light of the dramatic fall in asset values, is sound and would better reflect the returns of the portfolio in which the spending is based upon.

     The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support this Bill.

 

     Parliament is considering an important Constitutional amendment to our reserves framework.  The immediate issue before us is just a formula change.  How much income can the Government draw from the past reserves?  We are changing the formula.  The new formula will allow us to spend somewhat more.  But the deeper significance of this amendment is to establish a more sustainable and equitable basis for spending out of the investment returns.  Sustainable and equitable, so that we have resources which can benefit both the present generation and future generations.  While we spend for our needs, we also put aside a solid buffer for contingencies, for the proverbial rainy day.  That is the deeper meaning.  But the most fundamental significance of this amendment is that it reaffirms the importance of protecting our reserves and of upholding the two-key system of our Presidential safeguards.


     These reserves are a major resource for Singapore.  We have no natural resources.  All Members who enter this House memorise that as a catechism – no timber, no iron, no gas, no gold – just our wits and our strength and our financial reserves which we have built up.  And these financial reserves give people, Singaporeans and investors alike, confidence that Singapore is sound, strong and able to cope with anything which may come its way.  They are our nest egg and insurance for a rainy day.  So that even during tumultuous times like now, nobody has any doubt that we can weather the crisis.  Imagine that if we did not have these reserves, would anybody take us seriously if the Singapore Government issued a guarantee on all the bank deposits in Singapore – $700 billion of deposits – and we guarantee them? Guarantee them using what?  Would we have accumulated $700 billion of deposits in Singapore if we did not have that kind of economy and that kind of strength and solidity?  So people are prepared to bank here and to trust us.


     It has taken us more than 30 years to build up the reserves to where we are today.  We started accumulating them in the 1970s.  It was a favourable external environment, which allowed Singapore to grow strongly year after year.  We had a young population.  We did not need high social spending.  Healthcare was a very small proportion of our annual expenditure.  The Government could adopt and did adopt prudent and conservative fiscal policies.  And so we ran budget surpluses in good times, over many years and, in some years, huge budget surpluses.  We were lucky, we were careful, we were successful.  We collected the surpluses, we invested them carefully.  They became our reserves.


     At first, MAS managed them because MAS was the central bank.  MAS had to have enough to meet the needs for balance of payments – so many months of imports – and to meet the needs of managing the exchange rate so that nobody would try and have a go at the Singapore Dollar.  But when the reserves grew larger than what we needed for the Singapore Dollar and for our balance of payments, then Dr Goh Keng Swee decided to split off a separate organisation – GIC – from MAS, solely dedicated to managing the reserves for long-term returns.  This is so that it has only one mission – to manage the money.  It is not responsible for the financial system; it is not responsible for the exchange rate – just make this money grow.


     GIC was the forerunner of today’s sovereign wealth funds, not quite the first in the world, but one of the first.  It started with two employees initially, the Managing Director and his secretary, and now it has about 1,000 people working for it, from many nationalities, in offices here, London, New York and elsewhere.


     Besides GIC, we also built up the Government-linked companies.  We started them one by one – DBS, Sembawang, SIA, Keppel.  And as they grew, we transferred them over to Temasek Holdings to be managed commercially.  Because we decided the Ministers had better run Ministries, and Ministries should not be running companies.  Let us put the companies under proper holdings and proper management.  And so we have two professional investment organisations – GIC and Temasek – highly regarded around the world for their competence and integrity, and their track record.  They hire management internationally.  They are meritocratic.  They go by results.  They are focused on their commercial objectives and their Boards are competent and experienced.  They pursued sustainable returns over the long-term, and avoided excessive risk-taking for short-term gains.  In this way, we have achieved good returns through the ups and downs of the global economy and market cycles, not every year, but taking a long view, we have consistently done well.


     As our reserves grew, we became conscious and concerned about the need to protect them,

 

 

because we had seen other countries which had strong fiscal positions, but had become bankrupt, because of corruption, incompetence or populist but unsustainable measures.  We understood the nature of election politics.  There are strong pressures to spend more, either for short-term benefits or for political advantage, and every election could become an auction of populist policies to spend the reserves.


     For Singapore, the first generation of leaders and voters had gone through life and death political struggles and got Singapore out of poverty.  We could rely on the fiscal prudence of the Government and the good judgment of the people to safeguard our reserves and to hold the line politically.  To do the right thing and to convince people that this is the right thing and to stick by it – save, work, earn – not spend, relax, enjoy.  But for the long term, we knew that we had to institutionalise safeguards in the system because otherwise we would be in trouble, whether it is a PAP Government or a non-PAP government in power.  So we studied this carefully and took the first step in 1991, when we amended the Constitution to create the Elected President.


     The Elected President has a number of functions but protecting the reserves was one of the most important of them.  And our priority – the first big move we took – was to protect the principal sum of the reserves.  We said, "past reserves, all those accumulated by previous governments, that is what should be locked up.  Anything which the present Government accumulates, that is the right of the present Government to spend.  You earn the money; you have the right to decide what to do with it."  So we protected the principal sum of the past reserves, but we allowed the present Government to spend the income from those past reserves – which meant dividends and interests – on the argument that this is income which is accruing now and, therefore, it is income to the present Government.


     It was a simple approach but not a perfect one.  On the one hand, the Government could spend 100% of the income.  So we were not putting aside part of the income to grow the nest egg for the future.  But, on the other hand, when we said investment income, it was only interest and dividends.  We did not count capital gains and we did not count capital losses, and both capital gains and losses can be significant in managing money.  Also, we did not take inflation into account.  So, if inflation is high, you may think you are earning money and drawing only on the income when, in fact, you are drawing down on the reserves.


     But anyway, we had taken a first major step, to protect the principal sum of the past reserves.  Now, we had time to refine the scheme further as we gained experience with the new system.  We could sleep at night peacefully and think about how to improve the locks on the door, since the door had already been locked up.


     After this new system came into effect, we debated for several years how to refine the balance between providing for present needs, and building up the nest egg for the future. This was the question in the 1990s which many Members would remember as the hotly debated “Net Investment Income (NII)”.  The question is this.  We are spending 100% of net investment income-interest and dividends. What proportion of this actually should be made available to the Government to spend?  Should we lock up some proportion of the NII as past reserves?  Because, although it accrues now when this Government is in office, in fact, the reason that it is coming now is because the principal sum was built up before this Government came into office.  And if we are going to lock up some of it, how much would be reasonable?  How much is neither too stringent nor too lax?  How much is the right split between saving for the future and spending for now?


     The then President, Mr Ong Teng Cheong, had been a part of these discussions in Cabinet.  So when he became President, he was in favour of having the Government change the Constitution forthwith and lock up 50% of the NII.  But the Government was cautious.  We had already made one move earlier to lock up the principal sum.  We did not want to make another precipitate move, which might turn out to be too stringent or ill-judged, so we wanted to take more time to study this carefully.  We studied this for several years before eventually deciding that it was the right thing to do.  We decided on a 50-50 split between the present and the future, and implemented the new rule in 2001.  We could see the pressures were there.  MPs naturally want more social spending, and these are pressures which are understandable and which we have to take precautions to protect ourselves against.


     Why 50%?  It is not an exact science why we came to this number, but I think 50% has a certain neatness and feels intuitively acceptable, because it underlines our commitment to continue growing our reserves, while allowing the Government to tap on part of the investment income for current spending.  In a sense, we have put equal emphasis on both objectives – the present and the future.


    Thus we went from 100% to 50% of NII, but we were not yet ready to change the interest and dividends framework.  The other issues still remained – the question of capital gains and losses and the question of inflation.  These had not been tackled.


     We continued to study how we could improve our system.  We looked at other governments, like Hong Kong and Norway.  We studied some of the US Ivy League universities.  The US Ivy League universities are the best, most established, and also the wealthiest.  Some of them have built up huge endowments, and they have developed robust, sophisticated spending rules to preserve the value of their endowments, and generate a stable, sustainable income flow year after year.  They face very similar challenges as we do, though a little simpler because it is only within the university context.  They are only arguing with the professors how much money to spend, but the pressures are similar - how to grow it, how to have a stable flow, how to make sure that they do not overspend in good years and run out of money in bad years?


     And the most interesting of the models is that of Yale University, which had studied this very carefully and worked out a very systematic framework and run it for many years.  Fortunately, we had contacts with some of the people who operated the Yale endowments and we were able to pick their brains and understand how and why they did it this way.  But we had to take these ideas and fit them into the Singapore context.  There were three things we had to consider when we put them into the Singapore context.


     Firstly, economically, we needed a sound formula which would overcome the inadequacies of the present system.


     Secondly, politically, we needed a simple and fair system, which Singaporeans could understand and support and, most importantly, which can withstand political pressures to spend more.  And these are very difficult.  How to draw the line and stand firm, and not just say more is better?  That is a big challenge.


     Thirdly, constitutionally, we needed a scheme which would fit into our system of checks and balances, where the authority is split between Parliament which approves the money, the Government which decides what it wants to spend on, and the President who has custodial powers and can say no.  We had, specifically, to take full advantage of the institution of the Elected President with custodial powers.


    So, to take these theoretical ideas and fit them into our economic, political and constitutional requirements required many papers and a lot of work.  We came up with proposals repeatedly, we discussed them amongst the Ministers, the President, and the CPA.  We took in their views, and the matter went back and forth.  Finally, after many iterations, the result is this Constitutional amendment, which has the President's support.


     This amendment retains the principle of safeguarding 50% of our gains as past reserves, but it sets an important new basis for calculating the Net Investment Returns, and the key phrase is "long-term expected real returns" from our investments.  Every word means something.  "Long-term", because this set of rules looks beyond the current year, or even the next few years, because year-to-year or short-term conditions can be volatile and we want stability.  We are talking about long-term, which is something around 20 years.

  
     "Expected", because we are looking ahead, trying to judge prospects in a changing world rather than looking into the rear view mirror and going solely by past experience.  The past is a guide to the future, but the future is often different from the past.  If we look back over the last 20-30 years, those had been good years for markets, especially up till the dot-com boom.  Interest rates came down, economies and companies prospered, share values went up, and everything went up.  China was coming into the global economy, inflation stayed low, and it was a long boom.  If we look forward, there are black, storm clouds right now, but even beyond the storm clouds, I think it would be foolhardy for anybody to project that the future will be the same as the last 20-30 years, and to expect the same returns as we have been getting over the last 20-30 years.  So we have to look forward and decide what returns we can expect on a sustainable long-term basis.


     "Real" returns, because we have to take account of inflation, not just the amount in nominal dollars, because every year prices go up.  We have to account for inflation and subtract that out, and only deal with the real part of the returns.


     Then, we are talking about "returns", meaning not just income and dividends, but total returns.  Interest income, dividends, capital gains and losses – all forms of returns added together.  Therefore, we are looking at long-term expected real returns.  Memorise those words.


    The net effect of this change is to allow us to draw somewhat more than under the old formula, but we need to be careful how we are going to spend it.  Broadly, with this additional money, our priorities ought to be on investments in our future – as Mrs Josephine Teo suggested yesterday – on infrastructure, education and R&D, on increasing competitiveness and reducing direct taxes.  These are indeed the Government's priority areas in the years to come. So this Constitutional amendment will enable us to fund these programmes.

The additional money will enable us to invest in some very worthwhile things.

     If the Government is prudent and manages to accumulate surpluses in good years, then it is fair to share some of these surpluses with Singaporeans, eg, through the Progress Package, Growth Dividends and so on.  Those, naturally, come out of current reserves.  But if we need to spend more than we have available, then the Government of the day has to raise revenue to do this, and has to justify to voters why it is necessary to tax people in order to spend on these good causes.  Ms Sylvia Lim yesterday asked a question: will we need to burden the people further?  I think she meant it as a rhetorical question but I can give her a serious answer:  We cannot say.  It depends on what programmes the Government decides to embark on.  If we embark on an unconditional needs-based welfare system, such as the Workers' Party has proposed, then we will certainly add to the burdens of the people because then, the sky is the limit, and the money has to come from somewhere.  But for this PAP Government, only in an exceptional situation, to meet extraordinary, non-routine spending, would we go to the President and the CPA and make a case why we should draw more from past reserves.


     We have always to take a long-term view of these matters.  Right now, the global financial system is under severe stress.  Markets everywhere are in turmoil.  America, Europe, Japan, all three economies are in recession or going into recession, and these problems will take more than a few months to clear; at least a year, quite possibly longer.  Singapore cannot avoid the fallout.  Our economy is competitive, our banks are sound, but we are linked to the world.  As the Morgan Stanley economist Stephen Roach says, "You either believe in globalisation or you believe in decoupling.  You cannot be globalised and decoupled at the same time."  And Singapore is globalised, we are not decoupled.  So we have to be prepared for a rough time.  This year, we have cut our growth forecast to 3%.  In fact, the last two quarters (quarter-on-quarter) have been negative.  We cannot predict next year's growth yet, but we can be sure the next one or two years will be difficult.  Meanwhile, we are monitoring the environment and our economy very closely.  We are preparing measures to help businesses reduce costs, households, especially low-income households, to lighten their burdens, and workers to tide over the downturn.  By Budget next year in February, the situation will be clearer, and then we can decide what we will do.  We have the resources to do this, and we have the resilience to see ourselves through.


     This is quite a different outlook from the one we had when we decided to make this Constitutional amendment in 2006, just two years ago.  Growth in 2006 was more than 8%, the markets were booming, and our investments were doing brilliantly.  The formula we have come up with has to work in both circumstances.  Supposing we had spent all the investment income in a good year.  Then what will happen in bad years, when returns may well be negative, but when we most need the money?  Therefore, our spending rule will be based on long-term expected returns.  In good years, spend less than what we actually earn, and put aside more for the future.  In bad years, try to preserve the value of our investments, but draw on our accumulated surpluses at a prudent rate.  In this way, we can stabilise ourselves against volatility year-to-year.


     We did not time the Constitutional amendment to deal with this downturn.  It was not designed for this downturn.  But the amendment will put in place the right spending rule for this and future downturns as well as boom years.


     There is one question which I am sure many Members would have asked: in this recession, will we need to go to the President to spend more from past reserves?  My answer is this:  In a recession, our fiscal stance will naturally have to suit the prevailing conditions.  In other words, we naturally have to have looser budgets, the tax revenues will come down, the spending will go up, and we are likely to run a budget deficit.  Whether we run a deficit or a surplus, our policy will be dictated by economic considerations.  So if we can run a surplus, we will do so.  If we have to run a deficit, we will do so.  If as a result of having to run a deficit, we need to ask the President's permission to draw on past reserves, then we will seek the President's permission and justify why we need to do that.  But, fortunately, we have built up a comfortable buffer of current reserves since the last general election, which we can draw on if we have to run deficits over the next one or two years.  Hence, for now, I do not foresee the need to draw on past reserves to finance deficits in the ordinary course of the Government's business.


    But for exceptional contingencies, we will rely on past reserves and we will seek the President's permission to do so.  For example, the Government guarantee on bank deposits which we announced last week, which is backed by $150 billion of our reserves.  Mr Lim Hng Kiang, who is Deputy Chairman in MAS, has explained why and how we did this.  This is not a normal item; this is an exceptional item in an exceptional situation.  It is not a routine contingent liability which can be funded from this year's budget or even from the current reserves of this Government because this guarantee depends on the strength of the accumulated reserves of the Government.  We do not expect to use up $150 billion.  If we are lucky, very little of it will be drawn upon.  But everybody must be convinced that the $150 billion is real, that it is there, and should the guarantee ever be called upon, the guarantee will be good.  Therefore, this $150 billion is backed by our reserves.  In case there is a payout, the past reserves may be drawn upon.  This $150 billion has not been drawn yet, so it is not yet a draw on past reserves, but it is a contingent liability.  Depending on how things turn out, there could be a draw sometime down the road.


     Therefore, we sought the President's concurrence and the President consulted the CPA.  In fact, we briefed both the President and the CPA on what this was about, and they considered the matter and agreed that the Government could issue a guarantee.  This is the first time that the President is exercising his custodial powers to approve a potential draw on reserves in the almost 18 years that we have had the elected President system.


     This episode demonstrates three things.  First, how careful the Government has been with money and with reserves; secondly, the importance of having reserves in a crisis; and, thirdly, how the President exercises his gatekeeper function.


    The temptation to spend the money is always there, not just for Singapore but for other countries as well.  I am gratified that many MPs have reminded us to be careful and not to go down the slippery path, but the path is slippery and we have to walk without slipping.  Consider Norway – they discovered oil in the 1970s, and have become wealthy.  They set up a Petroleum Fund in 1990 because they did not want to spend all the money and then be left with nothing when the oil was gone, like so many other oil producers.  So they set up a Petroleum Fund in 1990 and put the proceeds from oil and gas sales into this fund to provide for the needs of the Norwegian population after the oil and gas reserves have run out.  Today, the fund has accumulated about US$350 billion.  But even in Norway, famously prudent, conservative, hardworking, frugal, Scandinavian people find it difficult to resist the populist push to spend just a little more.  Originally, the money was to be totally locked up until the oil ran out.  Then in 2001, they said no need to wait for the oil to run out.  Every year we can spend a portion of the real earnings of the Petroleum Fund in the budget. 

 

     The Norwegian Parliament set this as 4% of the value of the Fund.  In other words, they considered 4% being the expected long-term real returns.  But once they had set the rule, they broke the rule.  In 2002 to 2005, every year the Government exceeded 4% on the basis that the economy was not doing well and, therefore, it was necessary to be counter-cyclical and spend more.  In 2005, they renamed the Petroleum Fund as the “Government Pension Fund – Global”.  Actually, it is not a pension fund, but they call it the "Government Pension Fund – Global" to remind Norwegians that this is not money which is meant to be touched.  In 2006 and 2007, they spent less than 4%, not because they had gotten more stringent but because the oil prices went through the roof, and the Fund ballooned, so less than 4% was a lot of money.  But even then, some Norwegians still clamour for more.  In 2006, there was an article in Newsweek, which some Members may remember because the title is striking.  The title was "Trouble in Paradise", because this is a country which had everything – oil, gas, etc.  It was a welfare state, with all provided for, womb to tomb.  But still there was an opposition party arguing that you should pump more oil and make more profits, to improve services and lower taxes.  There is no way you can avoid these pressures.  Their elections are due next year, then we will see whether the majority of Norwegians continue to uphold the principle of saving for the future.  That is Norway.


     Australia provides another interesting example.  In the recent two general elections in 2004 and 2007, the parties have competed to give away goodies to voters, almost like an auction.  Australia also had a commodities boom because it has coal, iron ore, natural gas, uranium – the whole lot.  So, in 2004 during the elections, John Howard's government promised to set up a Future Fund to put away part of the budget surpluses to pay for superannuation for retired public employees in the future.  In other words, to pay for the future pension obligations of the government. 

 

 

 But, at the same time, John Howard also decided to roll out a package of goodies which eventually came to A$15 billion.  Some Australian reports explained how this happened.  His Treasurer, Peter Costello, had presented the Prime Minister with about 20 spending options for Howard to pick a few.  He had these 20 possibilities and, according to the report, the Treasurer watched in awe as the PM seized them all.  Costello said, "He ordered everything on the menu: the entree, the main course, the dessert, the vegetarian option."


     In the most recent election in 2007, Howard announced a A$34 billion tax package on the first day of the campaign.  The newspaper, Australian Financial Review noted, "Now that John Howard has put $34 billion on the election auction block, Kevin Rudd has little choice but to match him or even up the ante. It's just a matter of timing and presentation before Labor joins the bidding game."  And sure enough, Labor responded with its own A$31 billion package a few days later.  Major newspapers in Australia started to keep track of the cost of campaign promises.  They called it a 'pork-o-meter'.


     Eventually, John Howard's promises came up to A$65 billion, while Labor came to A$56 billion.  But, finally, the election was not decided on the 'pork-o-meter'.  Finally, in that case, the population just decided they wanted a change.  They have had enough of the Liberal government and chose Kevin Rudd over John Howard.


     I cite Norway and Australia not to criticise other countries.  I am just citing them to show that such is in the nature of election politics.  And to prove that, let me quote a passage by an American writer.  Who exactly wrote this is uncertain, but Ronald Reagan quoted this twice many years ago and it reads:


     "A democracy cannot exist as a permanent form of government. It can only exist until the voters discover that they can vote themselves largesse from the public treasury. From that moment on, the majority always votes for the candidates promising the most benefits from the public treasury with the result that a democracy always collapses over loose fiscal policy."


     This is the United States, the champion of democracy, and this is one view of the limitation of their system.  When John McCain talks about earmarks, he is really talking about pork.


     Singapore is not immune to these pressures.  We too face the reality of election politics.  Opposition parties often demand that the Government spend more, particularly near election time.  They never ask where the money will come from, least of all explain where the money for their programmes will come from at election time.  Therefore, we have to take extra care to safeguard our reserves for the future, to frame the rules to prevent our elections from becoming auctions.  Therefore, we need to put in place a system that will subject the government to tight fiscal discipline, regardless of which party is in power.  A system which has the support of the population and which is firmly anchored in our Constitution and cannot easily be altered.  And that is why we developed the system of a President who is directly elected to be the custodian of our reserves.  The President has the legal power and moral authority to say no to the government, if he judges any government action to draw on reserves to be detrimental to the future of Singapore.


     The Government does not have a free hand to spend the money, because the President holds the second key.  This provision binds the PAP Government too, but we support it.  In fact, we have imposed this discipline regime on ourselves when we could have chosen not to do so.  Why did we do this?  Because we believe that it is a vital safeguard for the future, and a responsible Government that adopts prudent budgeting practices will not be overly constrained by the system in its year-to-year operations.


     The President's position is intended to be entrenched in the Constitution so that if the Government disagrees with the President's decision, we cannot just change the powers of the President.  And the President's position is meant to be such that it cannot be altered by a routine Constitutional amendment – with a two-thirds vote in this House without the President's consent.  However, we have not yet entrenched the Constitutional provisions, as Prof. Thio Li-ann pointed out yesterday.  Prof. Thio also asked when we will do this, because it has been a long time since we created the system back in 1991.

  
     The answer is this. Our clear and stated intention is to refine the scheme and to iron out the issues that can arise in the light of experience, before we bring the entrenchment provisions into operation and entrench the rules.  Our experience since 1990 has shown that this is a wise approach.


     While we have delayed entrenching the scheme, we have, over the years, made a practice of consulting the President on any amendment which affects his powers, and informing Parliament of the President's view in the Second Reading speech.  With one exception, in practice, the President has supported all the amendments which affected his powers.


     Over the last two decades, we have fine-tuned and improved the system of the Elected President in many ways.  This present amendment on Net Investment Returns is a major refinement to the reserves protection framework.  Prof. Thio said that this is a technical change.  I think she is mistaken.  This is a major, important amendment.  After this amendment, we will operate the revised spending rule for a few years.  If after five years, no further major changes are necessary, we will consider entrenching the provisions concerning the President's custodial powers.


     It was significant that Ms Sylvia Lim, speaking yesterday on behalf of the Workers' Party, had supported this amendment.  It is a responsible approach; we applaud this.  It will help us to establish an important rule which both Government and Opposition will accept and uphold.


     We hope that the Workers' Party now accepts the wisdom of having an Elected President with custodial powers, because that is at the core of this Amendment and is what this whole structure depends upon, and will no longer campaign to abolish the Elected President as it did in the 2006 elections.


     Once all the parties accept that the reserves are not to be raided, we can avoid elections becoming auctions, paid for by mortgaging our children's future.


     We have a duty not just to govern Singapore properly today, but to do our best to safeguard the future of Singapore.  Our reserves are our nest egg.  It is not inherited by luck, but by hard work, prudent fiscal policies and sound investments over 30 years.  If we had to start from zero today, it would take us far longer to build up the reserves, if at all it were possible.


     The population is ageing, our spending needs are increasing and the economy is no longer growing at 8%-10% per year.  Furthermore, the global environment is uncertain.  It is unlikely that any global investor can repeat what we have achieved over the last 30 years.


     So, this proposed Constitutional change is a workable approach that strikes the right balance between present needs and the interests of future generations.  It will enable Singaporeans to benefit from our reserves, and yet conserve the value of what we have built, and continue to grow it over time as the economy itself grows. And this way, we can hand over to our children more than what we inherited from our forefathers.


     Sir, I therefore support the amendment.
